results.title: Song to Sing – Archie Roach
results.brief_description: Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for Wild Stallion Mountain (2015) clearly reflects that, playing like a mash-up of Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.
results.description: Strongly influenced by gospel in sound and style, ‘Song to Sing’ comes on the heels of Indigenous Australian musician Archie Roach suffering immense personal loss following the death of his partner two years earlier and his own health problems. The black and white video matches the uplifting rhythm of the track and features cameos from several prominent Australians including Roach himself, Jack Charles, Lou Bennett and Emma Donovan.
description_for_label: Strongly influenced by gospel in sound and style, ‘Song to Sing’ comes on the heels of Indigenous Australian musician Archie Roach suffering immense personal loss following the death of his partner two years earlier and his own health problems. The black and white video matches the uplifting rhythm of the track and features cameos from several prominent Australians including Roach himself, Jack Charles, Lou Bennett and Emma Donovan.

results.title: Song of the south
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Films Division, Government of India and V.R. Sarma
results.brief_description: Presents the Travancore-Cochin area of India, with a study of its arts, architecture and industries. Tea, rubber and cashew nuts are the main exports from Travancore-Cochin, and the growing of coconuts has developed the coir industry. The natural wealth of the area has in recent years facilitated the development of secondary industries such as aluminium, cement, rayon, ceramics, and chemical manufacture.

results.title: Song of the snows
results.creator_credit: K Khandpur, Films Division, Government of India and N.S. Thapa
results.brief_description: Out of the Himalayas rise the myths and legends, literature and culture of India. Shows the physical formation of snow, icicles, glaciers and rivers. This great mountain range is a challenge to mountaineers, a haven to pilgrims, and a source of immense beauty to all who come within its shadow.

results.title: Song of the prairie
results.brief_description: An animated puppet satire on the American western genre. Amusing stereotypes of typical characters from cowboy films which range from the whisky-swilling stagecoach driver and evil villain to the innocent heroine and singing hero. Music by Jan Rychlik.

results.title: Song of the paddle
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bill Brand, Marrin Canell and Bill Mason
results.brief_description: Outdoorsman Bill Mason takes his wife and two children on a wilderness canoe camping holiday. In this film the art of canoeing is more than technical expertise; it becomes a family experience of shared joy. Along the way there are countless adventures and much lovely scenery, including the Indian rock carvings of Lake Superior

results.title: Song of the Clyde
results.brief_description: A study of the Clyde River, from its source at Elvanfoot to its mouth a Glasgow. This ships built on Clydesdale are famous throughout the world. The film shows the docks, shipyards, and wharves which line the Clyde as it enters the sea. Written by Harold Purcell. Music composed by George Posford, arranged and conducted by Peter Yorke.

results.title: Song of the canary
results.brief_description: Coal miners once took caged canaries into the mines. By collapsing and dying, the tiny birds warned of the presence of deadly gases. Today workers themselves have become the canaries for other workers and society as a whole. The film examines lethal industrial-linked disease in factory workers as well as management and official indifference to this problem.

results.title: Song festival
results.creator_credit: Castle Films, Universal Pictures and Edward Cline
results.brief_description: Selection of songs from the film “What’s cookin’” (Universal) including ‘I’ll pray for you’ sung by the Andrews Sisters with Woody Herman and his Orchestra, ‘Il bacio’ featuring Gloria Jean and ‘Amen’ with Jane Frayee.
